participants.participant: José Luís San Pedro, Chief Operations Officer
José Luís del Valle, Chief Strategy and Development Officer, Chief Executive Officer of ScottishPower
José Sainz Armada, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good morning. Good morning, once again, and thank you for coming to our presentation this morning. Procedure will be as usual. We'll have the questions and answers right at the end. Without going into – without further delay, I'd like to give the floor to our next – sorry, first speaker.

Good morning. My presentation is just to give you the highlights of the period for the first quarter of this year, 2008. In general, for the Group, the key driver was the introduction to this group of ScottishPower and the new Iberdrola Renovables, which have increased production by 43% and installed capacity by 37.4%, about 10,000 megawatts; 6,000 of ScottishPower and 4,500 of Iberdrola Renovables.

Not only from an operating point of view has things changed for this company, but also from a financial perspectives, Renovables will now become about 19% weight yield and EBITDA of about 19%, and ScottishPower just over 25%.

My apologies for that. This increase in size that we experienced towards the end of the year 2007 has gone hand in hand with our strengthening of our financial, our purchasing power, plus an increase in profits. As we will show you, the EPA – the EPS for this first quarter is almost double the EPS we got in the first quarter of 2007.

Operating highlights. We have an output increased by 43.2% vis-à-vis the first quarter '07. And this increase in production was 2 million kilowatt-hour from Iberdrola Renovables, 7,000, I've got it from

ScottishPower, and 2,600 in Latam due to the result of the largest operation of one of our plants in South America. As for distributed – energy distributed is up 33%, most of this increase is thanks to ScottishPower, international ScottishPower internal group about 10,000 gigawatts/hour.

More highlights of the period, from a Group point of view, this slide sends out two clear messages; one that we continue to have a highly diversified generation mix. This is a key driver for value creation within the utility business, electricity business. And secondly, about 40% of our production is emissions-free, either hydraulic energy, wind and nuclear.

The breakdown per country; at present the electricity business in Spain accounts for less than half of the Group's business, and this trend will continue in the future. It is not likely that we'll be --continue to increase our capacity unless it's renewable.

Now looking at the deregulated business in Spain and Latam; the first bit of news that I want to share with you is the decrease in output in hydroelectric by almost a third. This decrease in hydro production, are basically three. First of all, the drought, the first quarter – I don't have the statistics with me, but it's probably the driest in history. So we – production hasn't even reached 2,000 gigawatts per hour, which is less than 30% for year and a half. This drop in hydro has had an impact on Iberdrola Group, more so than in the rest of the industry and therefore is one of the reasons why our production has dropped.

The second is the planned outages of our coal plants. The average availability was just only 23%. This is the result of plant outages, compulsory outages and investments in desulfurization plants and equipment. And the third reason was to optimize -- of gas contract portfolio.

Production through our combined cycle is probably double what we attained for the year 2007. That is still half of what we could have achieved. So why is there a decrease in output here? Well, we found more attractive margins for the sale of gas in the national and international markets. In fact, we sold in other markets, 8,000 gigawatts/hours of gas, which would be equivalent to a production in a combined cycle of about 4,000 gigawatts. These sales have given us a clean €24 million margin in this first quarter.

Another reason or driver for this period is the increase in the fuel prices. Coal; coal's average price is a $139 per ton which is 37% greater compared to first quarter '07. Brent, the average price is the $103 a barrel which is 15% more -- or rather it has increased gas prices by 15% vis-à-vis first quarter '07. With these prices, there are many, many gas and coal plants in Spain that can hardly cover the variable costs with prices ranging 60 to €65 per megawatt.
Pool prices have offset the increase in fuel prices and also the price of CO2 which is €23 a ton. Average for the pool is €75, but I think are about 60% greater than last year's.

Another – third factor of this, the regulated business, is development of forward markets. In the first quarter about 60% of the energy produced by Iberdrola was sold in forward markets. 50% to our retail branch and the other through the other branches. About 1,500 kilowatt-hour for a total of 2,358 megawatts -- kilowatts – gigawatts/hour. I think the average was about 56, and the retails I think it was more like €55. And we also have – and we've signed sales also for the rest of this year.

With – again with regards to the regulated business to – just two comments here. Demand is still on the rise with a moderate increase. Domestically in the first quarter, the demand was 2.4%. This is not terribly representative figure because this is a leap year, and that added a 1% increase. And second because we had Easter holiday in March. In last year, it was in April. So by offsetting these two factors, the first quarter really has an increase in demand equivalent to just over 2.4%.

Another key point is the publishing of the new remuneration framework, which still has a – which still needs of regulatory framework that's already being applied in 2008. And this has represented an increase for Iberdrola about 5 – by about 5%. And if we apply that to our figures by the year-end this might represent to our growth above 5.5%, or perhaps in closer to 6%.

Vis-à-vis Renovables, the green energy; two points that I would like to share with you. The first one is the first quarter results for this year. In Q1 2008, Iberdrola has achieved an EBITDA of €356.9 million, which doubles that obtained in the first quarter of 2007.

The drivers for this growth are two -- have three; the increase in our installed capacity, increase in production and average prices also are up. Increase in production was 67%, of which most of it is accounted for by the assets -- renewable assets of ScottishPower which have contributed 1,100 gigawatts/hour, and for Iberdrola Renovables in year 2007 our increase in output was just slightly greater than 8%.

The second growth driver of EBITDA was a price. The average price recorded is, Q1 2008 is almost 12% greater, higher than Q1 2007, despite the dollars devaluation by 13% and in GBP evaluation of 8%. In Spain, our price rises are about 30%, vis-à-vis less there for two reasons. On the one hand, we have the increased pool prices and an increase in our CO2 emissions, and also the loans prices that we found in the year 2007, where in Q1 '07 prices were actually below €40 gigawatt hour.

The second point I would like to highlight here for this period and for – I think Renovables is the construction, the rate of construction, as you know, the value of Iberdrola Renovables is not based on our short-term results. Renovables value is based on its growth, ability to grow. In the first quarter, we have installed 460 megawatts; 110 in Spain, 248 in United States and 112 in rest of the world. This 460 megawatt represents 23% of our target for 2008, which is 2,000 megawatts. In the first quarter, the new installed capacity generally – is generally about 12% for the year. At present, our pace is about double what we have done in previous years. So instead of 12, we were really up to 23% in the full capacity.

In addition to 31 March, 2008, we had in the pipeline was – sorry, that's currently at a construction 1,367 megawatts; 454 in United States, 359 in the UK and a 171 in the rest of world. And we're shortly beginning construction in the second quarter of 640 megawatts, and additional 640 megawatts is our target for this year, which I believe was 2,065 gigawatts – sorry, megawatts for this year. We are quite likely to attain – achieve this target for the year.

Now, putting into production new megawatts means that we have reduced our – to reduce our total pipeline, so – and therefore, may limit our growth in the future to overcome this problem. In the first quarter we've already added to our investment pipeline that we already had a 43,000 megawatts, we've added another 1,227 megawatts. So again, our growth – our future growth is guaranteed, in fact greater than last year.

Two more comments regarding Latam where there has been no – nothing new to report. In Mexico one of the – a good thing is that we have earned considerable increase in production. As I said about 2,500 gigawatts/hour thanks to the launch of the new plant. And we also have high prices in gas, which doesn't have an impact upon our customers – or pass through, that is, our margin, however, in dollars is an increase – well that's an increase of 7%, and this has not offset the devaluation of the US dollar, which has been 13%. So in March from Mexico, the business has been slightly negative, of course, from result point of view.

As for Brazil, the demand for our distribution has grown by 8%. Energy prices have been very high, has had a gross margin, considerable gross margin, and we are now reviewing tariffs in Coelba, Cosern and Guatemala. The rates are being upgraded to the value of the assets that in the last few years we have been introducing to our system and also the value of the operating expenses.

And lastly, the financial costs or asset remuneration, there has been a considerable decrease in cost of financing in Brazil. So we expect a decrease in rates, which will affect our margin. But we don't believe that will affect our net profit in these parts.
And that's it. Without further delay, I'd like to give the floor now to José Luis del Valle, who will talk to you about the keys – the highlights of ScottishPower.

Thank you very much, José. Good morning to all of you. ScottishPower continues to improve its financial operating results across all its branches and activities in generation through the increase in production of about 15.5%, reaching 6.9 terawatts/hour.

In retail, tariff increases over 14% in electricity and 15% in gas, which took place in February. Networks; thanks to the increase in the value of the assets and the new investments and – of the new projects, the new value of the assets are about 3,287 million pounds. And overall, the EBITDA of the company, which excluding the mark-to-market adjustment actually goes 10%, up to 327.2 million pounds.

Let me give you more details on each of these points, to start with generation. Increased output up to 6.9 terawatts/hour was made it possible; thanks to the greater availability of our production plants and also the margins in the market are profitable with profitable spreads.

All this was possible despite the fact that our CO2, that our coal plants have been affected by the scheduled shutdowns to conduct environmental investments, mostly in desulfurization assets. But that's been offset also by a greater availability and flexibility of the CC – of our CCGT plants, our combined cycle gas plants, which have increased our availability to the market.

On the other hand, and as you may well know ScottishPower has a pretty balanced situation between production and sales to retail customers. This balance gives the Group a natural hedge between generation and retail power. And therefore these operations also the management team of ScottishPower were capable, continue to decrease the procurement costs of gas and coal to the values at prices lower than current market prices.

So to summarize for this first quarter in retail and the financial performance of the company have gone up. We have been optimizing our results in generation. And as a result, we've had a very good operating and financial results.

In retail, there is good financial operating results. Clearly, seen from the results and I mentioned earlier, the increased in the gas rates and electricity rates, which was implemented in February, gas went up by 15%, electricity went up by 14% in order to reflect the increase in generation costs.
We believe there is also a cost reduction target, reduction by – of a 150 million per annum to the year 2010. As of this date, we have attained a cost reduction that annualized is over 30 million.

In retail, we've also decreased complaints to Energywatch of about 69% year on year, and also domestic – debtor days for domestic customers down 10%. So again, we continue with a very good performance and increased return, very much in line with our plant.

Energy networks; again, we are meeting our target as well as our investment plans. And of course, all this means that we have a better return, more similar or superior to the cost of capital. We have invested about a €100 million for the first quarter, which is about 31% in new growth projects.

As I said, the regulated asset value increased to 3,287 million pounds. And as I said, we're also managing to lower our costs, thanks to our greater purchasing power, since it now belongs to the Iberdrola Group that increases its purchasing power. And we continue to improve our network performance as you can see on the right hand side by chart, we're also reducing by about 15% the number of network interruptions, when you compare the first quarter of '07 with Q1 '08.

Now, looking at the company. At the Group, we have implemented a new management model and which has enabled us to focus on synergies, obtaining those synergies and integrate the businesses within the Iberdrola Group.

Synergies are being delivered based on our targets, and at corporate level they are – is what we are obtaining most of these synergies where operations overlap with Iberdrola. These are the controllable costs down – controllable costs write-down 7.1 million pounds, in other words 47.4% lower than in Q – than Q1 '07.

We've also achieving lower procurement costs, thanks to that increase in purchasing power that I mentioned. And we also have a future improvement in IT costs, thanks to the investment plan that we have introduced.

So these synergies can clearly be seen. And if we'll take a look at the development of the staff, including the agencies and external parties compared to the same quarter of last year, this workforce has fallen by 8.2%. And as a result, the overall gross personnel costs, even the capitalized ones, is – represent the fall of 10.5%, thanks to all of this. We are reducing by 11.5% in our expenses, as a result of the integration synergies and this has a positive impact on achieving this greater EBITDA, which, as I said at the beginning, has risen by 10% up to 327.2 million pounds in – during the period, if we exclude the adjustment mark-to-market impact.

Now, I'm just going to briefly talk about the situation of the authorization processes of our transaction with Energy East. Updating what, we already said, when we talked about the results for – at the beginning of 2007 at that time, we said that we had obtained all of the all federal authorizations for that approval.

Now, the competition, the Hart-Scott-Rodino, the Federal Communications Commission, the FCC, the Exon-Florio authorizations and those of the Federal Energy Commission, the FERC, we have obtained all of these in a record time, I believe.

We've also obtained authorizations from different states; the Connecticut, New Hampshire, Maine, Massachusetts. In Massachusetts we didn't need that authorization actually. What is left? What we still need in New York? New York, we said that the objective was to achieve this in the first semester, the first half of 2008. We believe that we still can obtain that authorization within this first half of 2008.

And now, specifically talking about that situation in New York, we're trying to reach an agreed solution with the technical services of the commission, and we're – we've tried to do this on a number of occasions, but it was not possible. So, we had to go to in arbitration situation on the regulation. So, in this proceeding on the 16th to the 20th of March, we expressed our different conditions, as the technical people did in the – from the commission.

On the 11th of April, we presented our reach, and now we have 10 days to respond and make the – may have made the different response to what the commission's technical services have stated. We also should mention that the commission's technical services wanted to delay the process due to those speculations, those rumors on corporate on moves regarding Iberdrola. The judge said that it was not justified – this delay was not justified, unless there was specific proof that an operation was imminent.

Therefore, as we all know, that is not the case. Therefore, this situation has been resolved. So we are focusing now on the reach that we need to respond to what the commission has says at the end of the May according to the schedule, the administrative judge will have to make, a recommendation to the commission.

This is not binding, but it is a very good indication of where things will – that things will probably take not in terms of the technical services of the commission, but the commissioners themselves, the commission itself has to take a decision in this connection. There is no calendar set up. They don't have any time limit. But we expect that this will take place in June. But as we said, we don't have any guarantee, because they do not have a deadline. If the decision is favorable and may be conditions are reasonable as we expect, and we do get this authorization in June end, immediately, we will close the transaction.
Thanks very much for your attention. And now, our Economic Financial Director will take the floor. Thank you.
Thanks, José Luis. As usual, we're going to take a look now at the different aspects -- the most important aspects of the results of 2008 to then analyze in more detail the most relevant areas.

The net profit has grown by almost a 163% up to €1.2 billion with good operational growth of 64% – 64.7% EBITDA for Renovables, which is increase of 111%, and ScottishPower contributed 28.3% of the EBITDA to the group. We should also point out a positive impact given the improved efficiency with net operating expenses below the basic margin.

Also past evolution of the operational results, we also have the benefit of the divestment of asset, the non-core assets in compliance with the Strategic Plan 2008 – 2010. And in this divestment, we talk about the sale of 4% of our participation in Galp, which gave us some capital gain of almost €390 million. Therefore, the results of this first trimester, this first quarter showed strong growth in all areas reach above 60% on the operational level reaching this increase of 163% in terms of net profit.

If we take a look now at the development of the profit and loss statement -- with the income statement, we see growth in all areas, they go from 5.5% in terms of operating position up to 69.5% in terms of net profit within EBITDA growing by 8.7%. This comparison shows once again the quality of the income statement – Iberdrola's income statement.

Now let's take a look at the different items. The revenues have grown by 132% up to €6.3 billion with important growth in all the businesses, given the rise in energy prices in 2008, greater activity and the change of the parameter given the entrance of ScottishPower. Sales in Renewable grew by 146%. Energy in Spain grew by 53.4%. ScottishPower contributed €2.2 billion. And in terms of the rest of the businesses in Latin America grew by 39% given the Tamazunchale plant and the gas prices and non-energy by 18.3% given the engineering part of the business.

So within this environment of rising costs and the parameter our procurement has also risen by 260% up to €3.5 billion. By business procurement of energy grew by 120% given the different production mix and the lower hydro production. And cost by procurement has risen by €74 billion, ScottishPower had 1.4 billion, and Latin America grew by 68% given the greater production of Tamazunchale which entered into operation in 2007 and the rise in the cost of gas. The gross margin grew by 62.3% to €2.5 billion and the energy businesses spend reached 1.23 billion with a growth of 11.5%, both the liberalized with 16.1% and the regulated business with 4.4% show positive growth.

As responsible for that growth, first of all, we have Renovables with a growth of 109% given the standardization of the back to – back on track of the wind power and ScottishPower, that's contributing 25.6%, €653.6 billion. Latin America also grew with a rise of 1.4% to €270 million. Non-energy fell by 2.7% given the fall in the activity of the real estate which is offset by the growth in engineering.

And to assess the net impact of the emissions rates on the profit and loss statement, we should look at the basic margin, which grows by 68.9%, almost 7 points greater than the growth of the – in foreign gross margin. This is because the foreign gross margin that we reflect in our statement only accounts for a negative impact of the emissions rates that were used up which are €154 million. And the basic margins obtained by adding to that gross margin, the positive effect, that €107 billion arising from the fee rates – the fee assigned rates and this – so this allows for the net effect of these rates in the statement which is negative €47 million.

And this quarter the net operational cost grew by 58.1% to €694 million and this – which is growth by almost 11% below the basic margin. In Iberdrola we have a 7.7% growth to €420 million in a quarter where we've had the updating of the salary, of course, given the collective bargaining agreement in ScottishPower has or was 27% with €185 million.

Renovables increased by 96% and expenses to €81 million as a result of the growth – the expansion of its activity and the different parameter of consolidation due to the inclusion of PPM and the UK Renovables.

Now in terms of levies that grew very sharply by the €84 million for the detraction – for the subtraction, the CO2 rates crawled back. This was in provision of the application in 2008 of Royal Decree 11/2007, and the ministerial order from 16th of November on the subtraction of emission rates. This regulation has been appealed, as you know. We do consider, however, that this possible subtraction of rights is an obligation as a callback – an additional callback, ScottishPower contributes €23 million to that levy.

Our consolidated EBITDA grew by 64.7%, reaching €1.79 billion. Energy business in Spain is 630 million with a growth of 4.2%, which will be 18% if we excluded that 84 million that we mentioned, due to this rate subtraction that we talked about before. As we said during – as we mentioned during this presentation, both, ScottishPower and Renovables are the main drivers behind the EBITDA growth of the group. And Renovables more than double its contribution to 337.9 million.

Latin America moderates its growth by – at 4.9% in a year, where as José Luis mentioned we are foreseeing tariff changes and the weakness of the dollar that's affecting business in Mexico. Energy is falls by 14.8% affected by the decreased activity in real estate. The informed EBITDA has different impacts which are offset by one another, both of these effects are due to ScottishPower and Renovables both in the United States and in the UK.

The effect on the exchange rate is almost €58 million less than it would have been one year ago. And the effect of mark-to-market is 52 million more in net terms. So, the EBITDA, excluding those two terms, would be 1.79 billion with a growth of just over 65%.

The EBITDA of the group grew by 65.8%, reaching €1.318 billion, very much in line with the development in EBITDA. We have 61.2% growth with 52% accounted for by the partners in Iberdrola Renovables. This is due to the growth of D&A in 63.7%, and D&A from ScottishPower are €127 million and arrives from both the acquisition of the assets of the company as well as the D&A of the overpricing of the assets, the PPA which accounts for €61 million of which Renovables contributes 21 million. The provision – procurement goes to €7 million.

The financial results of the group rose by 38.1% to €225.8 billion. This is a growth that is less than the average debt over the period which grew by more than 50%, close to €21 billion. Thanks to the positive impact from the hedging. As we mentioned, Iberdrola has hedged the exchange rate of the pound during 2008.

The average cost of the debt is to 4.7 to 5.1% due to the incorporation of the pound – the impact in pound and the tax equity investors and the interest rates – interbank interest rates of the euro, our main currency.

The income before tax rose by 150%. And the EBIT – and the financial result, we have to add the impact of €536 million, which are non-recurring, deriving, first of all, from the capital gains of €386 million obtained through the sale 4% of our participation in Galp and the adjustment, when committed, to the participation package of BBVA; that was €112 million and the capital gain of almost €37 million through the sale of Veo television.

The net profit grew by 163% up to €1.24 billion and this growth is greater than the profit before taxes, given the higher tax rate, which is around 25%. The main causes of this reduction are reduction in the tax – state tax rate in Spain at around 30%; the exemptions from the regional taxes, the UK situation which is around 28%, and the application of the reinvestment and the divestment factors. The funds generated by operations continue to grow with a growth of 55% to €1.2 billion.

Also I'd like to point out that the cash flow, the EPS is – had a growth of 90 – almost 90%. Analyzing the results by business and looking at the liberalized business in Spain, including the retail and wholesale, we have a growth 84% of the pool and 2.5% in demand. Demand growth of 2.5% which offsets that lower production of 13.6%, this fall is due to a different mix in the production with 66% in water production and 28% in the conventional, given the environmental work done at our plants, which was not offset by the greater nuclear recharge in 2007 or the strong growth of 40% in the combined cycle output.

They do have a lower use of the combined cycle due to the optimization process. As Luis San Pedro mentioned, the average cost of fuel grew to €47.3 per megawatt hour, so those are rising commodities on the international level and the – also a rise in CO2 emissions cost.

The rise in the fuel cost is reflected in the cost of fuel and CO2. All of this has translated into an increase in the gross margin at the liberalized market in Spain of 16.1% up to €637 million. As a result the growth in generation and the commercial areas of non-regulated gas have been over than the rise in the procurement cost of the business. In terms of basic margins, adding the emission rates, the growth reached 23.8%.

EBITDA of liberalized electricity was been 237 million – 376 million, that's 4.7% increase. And if we include those €32 million of the gas in the total EBITDA will be almost €409 million as your growth of also 4.7%. We should point out that the EBITDA of the business is also affected by the impact of those €84 million. Excluding the impact of EBITDA it would have grown by 26%, if it weren't for that affect.

In terms of Renovable, we have a growth of 79.7% of the 4.89 gigawatts, and in terms of the installed capacity, which reaches 79.3% up to 8164 megawatts. The Renovable production in the first quarter of 2008 increased thanks to the operational efficiency of the business in May, despite the January and February low wind months, this, together with greater average prices of 11.7% ensure that the gross margin of the group grew by 109%. However we should remember that there has been a change in the parameter given the entrance of PPM and Renovables and the UK EBITDA excluding the impact of the mark-to-markets of €19 million – negative euros could reach almost €337 million. This is due to the devaluation of the gas contracts in the market and has nothing to do with the wind business.

The net operational cost has grown by 97%. And this growth is linked basically to the expansion cost, the international part of the business and the increase of expense in Spain only grew 10% in Spain.

The gross margin of the regulated business in Spain grew by 4.4% to €387 million and this is a result of the – positive effect of the increased individual remuneration of the regulation due to that Royal Decree. EBITDA has fallen by 1% as a result of two – no recurring impacts in terms of personnel cost. The reversion of the forecast for the regulation for the first quarter 2007 and the application, as I mentioned, of the updates of the salaries due to the application of the collective bargaining agreement, this development will be analyzed throughout the rest of the year.

The ScottishPower, in terms of gross margin, has been – was €578 million. And in terms of basic margin – adding goes to €62 million of the emissions rate, the participation gets to €640 million. And the level of EBITDA in the participation is €507 million which means 28.3% of the group's EBITDA.

EBITDA of ScottishPower, €226 million, means the wholesale and retail business; and the €270 million to the other part of the business. And mark-to-market – positive mark-to-market is €71 million. And the exchange rate in fact has taken about €43 million of EBITDA.

EBITDA in Latin America has grown moderately at 4.9% to €210.3 million. In local currency EBITDA is 5.2% and 4.9 in foreign EBITDA given that the exchange rate in the two business areas, in Mexico and the other, is different and they offset one another.

We should also point out that we have the strict control cost with – that was actually 8.2 cost of operation – net operational cost, so we can approve the EBITDA given the gross margin which rose by 1.4%. As I – Jose Luis already mentioned, EBITDA in South America reaches €235.2 million showing a growth of 13.5% rising basically from the increase of 8% in demand, and is affected by their possible greater remuneration of distributors affecting us during 2008.

And we will have – in Coelba and Cosern we will have changing in fees. The change will – is positive 6.9%. In terms of Guatemala and Mexico we have €75 million. And we should see a fall of 7.6% negative impact given the exchange rate and the negative effects given the deviations in margin and the non-recurration of tariff assess in Guatemala offset the positive affect of the growth in the Tamazunchale plant.

In terms of non-energetic engineering fell by 14.8% to €105 million. As I explain in the next slide greater activity in real estate is not offset by the strong increase in the engineering and construction. Iberdrola real estate decreases its share given the fall in the real estate during the first quarter of 2007. The results has €37 million to – the sale of the land for the last part of Chiloeches. Thanks to the diversified model and with a contribution to leasing and sale that can offset lower – the low contributions from the other areas.

And we will also maintain – adjusted our very trade cost that allow real estate to continue to give positive results to the group given the market – despite the market situation construction is still growing. The sales to third-parties grew by 83% and the pipeline of projects is now €3 billion, which guarantees strong activity over the next several years. Therefore, we have strong growth in the business, both in terms of gross margin which grew 43.4%, and EBITDA, with a growth of 36.8%.

Now, I am going to quickly talk about some – our financing. Because the market situation is interesting and after the acquisition of ScottishPower, the balance of the Company has been strengthened with total assets of 70 million – €70.2 billion with 106% growth. This has been achieved by a greater flexibility of the financial structure of the Company. We've reduced the financial debt in the balance from 40 – 31 – from 42 to 31. We have also doubled the equity away from 20 to 40%. That increase in equity – as a result, we have a very strong improvement in leverage of the Company which has been reduced from 55% to 40.9%, excluding the impact of the tariff insufficiency we can reach 39% equity increased by 172%, very much above the increase in the net adjusted debt.

We have also firmed up the financial situation – the solid financial situation of the Company, as of now to make investment in our strategic plan, maintaining the – our financial strength. Iberdrola looks at a tariff deficit which will be 35% of the deficit estimated for the entire sector. This calculation looks at all of the emissions rate for this sector in accordance with Royal Decree 11/2007. The financial ratios have improved so the front – on the net debt have improved from 23 to 27% and the cash flow over that debt have improved from 16 to – over 20%.

Our position of liquidity is also very good. We finished the first quarter with almost €11 billion in liquidity, which allows us to deal with the strategic plan 2008 with ease. And expectation that complying with all of the interests, we will be able to maintain a very positive position in terms of liquidity from now till the end of the year.

And just to finish up this presentation, and focusing now on the perspectives of the entire year 2008. I would like to point out that the government forecast for the main – the core business – look at 2008 as a very strong growth year. A continued good trend after a very good first quarter; above average, Iberdrola Renovables will surpass the objectives established for 2008, and ScottishPower will contribute to the results. The results for 12 full months and in excess, in a year, we will a good performance, which is due to the synergies and cost savings. Iberdrola will also have good performance in 2008, better than 2007. And all of this will take us to a situation where our forecast will be strong growth for this year. Thanks very much.
Now, we are going to go to the question-and-answer session.
Okay. Well, let's start the questions in this room, Raimundo from Credit Suisse.

Thank you very much. Two questions, on Energy East, I would like to ask. In the event that the conditions faced by the commission were not acceptable, would Iberdrola give up this proposal? Do you have any other alternatives in mind? Considering the casual increase they had made last year? There have been statements or anything that the company that there were other potential targets in the US. Starting with gas, in the UK, we have tranches of long-term gas contracts which have been secured over the last 10, 12, 15 years, in some cases shorter. But those tranches of gas are the – they are the underlying gas cover position we have. And obviously these contracts were put in place taking when gas prices were lower. And at the same time, we supplement that base of long-term gas with a rolling approach to purchasing gas for our retail and our generation needs. So when I say rolling, we buy progressively in the period of two or three years ahead. And we – it's not completely mechanistic, it's not a case of a third every year. And so – and the situation of coal is kind of similar. We've purchased the coal that we need for our generating on a rolling basis. We don't go and buy everything we need four years ahead, but neither do we wait until the day or the month, the week ahead. It's a rolling basis which tends to smooth out some of the volatility we've seen. And also in the case of renewable we have a rising coal price globally.
